description.narrative:
Moçambiques regering och UNDP har bett givarna att bidra till det Nationella Minröjningsprogrammet för att landet ska kunna uppfylla sitt åtagande under Ottawakonventionens artikel 5, enligt vilken Moçambique ska ha röjt och förstört alla kända personminor i mars 2014. Förutom att orsaka dödsfall och olyckor så begränsar minorna människors och varors fria rörlighet, hindrar utvecklingen av infrastruktur och gör produktiv mark obrukbar. Detta påverkar särskilt negativt de lokalsammhällen som finns nära minfälten.
Det initiala stödet sträckte sig till mars 2014, men flertalet faktorer har omöjliggjort måluppfyllelsen inom den tidsramen. Bland annat har 22.2 miljoner kvadratmeter nya minfält identifieras och arbetet har också försvårats och försenats på grund av översvämningar, säkerhetsläget i de norra delarna av Moçambique och komplikationer med minröjning vid gränsen till Zimbabwe. UNDP efterfågade därför en förlängning av kontraktet till december 2014.
Den föreslagna insatsen förväntas bidra till att samtliga kända minfält rensas från minor senast i december 2014 samt till att såväl myndigheter som lokasamhällen utvecklar en grundläggande kapacitet att hantera explosiva krigsrester som kan dyka upp i framtiden. Projektet har utvecklats inom ramen för Moçambiques Nationella Minröjningsplan 2012-2014 och regeringens ägarskap av detsamma bedöms vara starkt. UNDP bedöms ha den kapacitet och de resurser som krävs för att tillförsäkra måluppfyllelse och ett effektivt utnyttjande av resurserna. Det finns risker som kan kompromettera måluppfyllelsen, men dessa bedöms vara måttliga och hanterbara.
The objective of the project is to help ensure that Mozambique is able to live up to its committment in the Ottawa Convention of eliminating all personnel mines in the country by March 2014

sector.narrative: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: In terms of outcomes, during the reporting period, IND and UNDP regularly organized mine action stakeholder forums and other coordination meetings to monitor and exchange information on demining activities. The IND staff actively participated in international debates and discussions on demining, learning from experience of other countries and sharing Mozambique’s experience, in particular on land release and mechanical demining. Despite the military conflict, mine clearance activities were conducted by four demining operators and completed as planned in the provinces of Inhambane, Manica, Sofala and Tete, . In total, the humanitarian mine action activities financially supported by Sweden contributed to the clearance and release of 93 suspected or confirmed hazard areas covering a total of 6,496,965 square meters, including 266 electrical pylons along the Beira I and Beira II power lines, and the destruction of 21,918 anti-personnel landmines, 4 anti-vehicle mines and 396 items of unexploded ordnance. The mine action quality management system continued to be used by IND Quality Assurance team. The IND QA team undertook 508 monitoring missions of the demining operations of the UNDP funded mine action operators. These visits covered the provinces of Inhambane, Maputo, Manica, Sofala and Tete. During the visits, the progress of demining operations under way were evaluated, as well as the ability of operators’ capacity in terms of personnel, equipment, degree of compliance with the Mozambican National Mine Action Standards. This involves: command and control system, marking, manual demining, mechanical demining, animal mine detectors and emergency medical response. The IND QA Team also conducts post-demining assessments to confirm conclusion of demining tasks as part of the government’s Mine-Free District Evaluations. As a result of the humanitarian mine action and quality assurance activities supported by the government of Sweden, Mozambique made good progress by declaring the country free of land mines. This is evident in the number of mine-free districts that increased from the start of 2013 from 105 districts to 124 districts at the end of 2014 out of a total of 128 districts in Mozambique. While Mozambique fell short of its goal of classifying all 128 Districts as free of all known mined areas by the end of 2014, IND continued to work and cleaned the remaining 4 districts in Sofala and Manica as mine free in 2015. Despite the tremendous progress achieved during the project period, Mozambique still faced several challenges to complete demining by the deadline established by the Anti-Personnel Mine Ban Convention. As part of the regular evaluation of mine action progress, the National Demining Institute and the Government of Mozambique determined that Mozambique needed an additional 10-months to complete their obligations to clear all known mined areas in accordance with Article 5 of the Mine Ban Convention. In 2013, the Government of Mozambique therefore submitted and was granted a request to extend the Mozambique’s deadline to comply with article 5 of the Mine Ban Convention until December 2014. Nonetheless, at the coordination meeting in January 2015, the demining operators informed all partners that, despite tremendous progress, they were unable to clear all known mined areas by the December 31 deadline, thus the National Demining Institute formally requested that three operators needed to continue and clear the remaining areas by 4 April 2015. Thanks to the support of a number of partners, Mozambique came only to completing implementation by September 2015, when the Government declared Mozambique as a “landmine free” country.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
